name: Enforce SSO when possible
description: ## Why? To minimize the risk of unauthorized access, it's important to centralize and secure authentication across your organization. Single Sign-On (SSO) enhances security by enabling better control over account access, enforcing consistent security policies (e.g., 2FA), and making it easier to revoke access when someone leaves the organization.

name: Implement email filtering and warning system
description: ## Why?  As you know ⇒ email is the most common entry point. Each phishing email filtered out of your employee mailbox is less mental load for you and your employees and less risk faced by your company.  ## What? You need to configure your email system to scan all incoming emails for potential threats

name: Implement email authentication (DMARC)
description: ## Why? DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) helps prevent email spoofing and phishing attacks by verifying the authenticity of emails sent from your domain. It will do two things: ⇒ your recipient will know for sure it is coming from you and it will protect your company reputation (with gmail and cie). ⇒ you will be sure (if activated) that the email you received is really from the said company (if they configured DMARC as well)

name: Run performance reviews
description: ## Why? Makes sure your team has the skills and focus needed to protect what matters most in your business. They help spot training gaps, reinforce accountability and ensure everyone is aligned with your operational goals - security being one of them. It's all about building a culture that proactively minimizes risks while continuously improving. ## What? Create a simple employee performance evaluation process. It must rely on clear metrics and expectations and must be run at least once a year.

name: Clearly explain your services
description: ## Why? A proper service description is key for your customers, but it also help the auditor understands what your customers are expecting from you.Here, we are not enhancing security, we are helping the auditor be more efficient. As part of the audit, he/she will need to understand clear boundaries for the audit, identify the relevant risk and then check how you mitigate them.

name: Have a security page
description: ## Why? Customers and other external users are provided with information on how to report systems failures, incidents, concerns, and other complaints to appropriate personnel. Also, having compliance for yourself is useless, you want to leverage it as much as possible.

name: External support available
description: ## Why? External support is not required, but it enhances transparency by showcasing your security practices, policies, and compliance efforts, building trust with customers and stakeholders. Ultimately, this is what compliance is about: reassuring your prospect and customer on how you work. ## What?  Create and maintain a complete list of support resources (eg. user guides, technical documentation) for all your services. Ensure easy access to those resources and keep them up to date.

name: Implement IAM for database authentication
description: ## Why? You want to ensure that only the proper people can access your production database. You also want to avoid the burden of managing another list of users or rotating credentials.

name: Plug your infrastructure & GitHub - avoid lifetime tokens
description: ## Why? Having credentials to manage can become a nightmare (especially if you need to change/rotate them often) - it quickly becomes time consuming. It is the same with lifetime tokens - someone leaving and you need to change them.

name: Setup a password manager
description: ## Why? In order to minimize the threat of someone getting access to something they should not, we want to ensure a few things: 1. The password used in your company are complex enough. 2. They are stored encrypted. 3. They are shared safely when needed (not openly, on slack or by text). 4. They are not compromised. The easiest way to implement those is to use a password manager.

name: Use VPNs to secure access for remote devices
description: ## Why?In short, implementing a VPN will encrypt your data and ensure a safe transmission between your employees devices and your internal network (even when using untrusted networks like a public wifi) ⇒ it offers a layer of security for your data. If everything is on Google Suite/Notion/Slack/etc. with MFA and you don't have your own network => ignore this mitigation.

name: Automated backup
description: ## Why? Automated backups ensure that your data—one of your company’s most important assets—is regularly and securely saved, reducing the risk of data loss. The back-up keeps it safe and available, while the automated and regular aspect allows for a restoration just before any disruption, minimizing loss.

name: Create & test your disaster recovery plan
description: ## Why? Disasters might seem far-fetched, but data loss, service outages, and misconfigurations can happen. Whether it's a simple human error or a regional outage, a disaster recovery plan helps your team recover fast and maintain customer trust.

name: Define BCDR objectives
description: ## Why? Defining precise BCDR objectives ensures you can effectively prepare for disruptions, clearly measure downtime thresholds, and communicate recovery expectations to stakeholders and third-party providers, reducing confusion and minimizing the impact of potential disasters.

name: Evaluate your vendors
description: ## Why? Create an inventory of your vendors, evaluate their risk level and review them regularly

name: Insert security clause in third-party contracts
description: ## Why? Strong contractual language ensures third parties protect your data with the same rigor you do, lowering supply-chain risk and establishing clear accountability.

name: Require signed NDA with critical third parties
description: ## Why? NDAs formalize confidentiality expectations and legal protections, minimizing the risk of data leakage or misuse by external entities who handle or access proprietary information.

name: Create a security communication plan
description: ## Why? A defined communication plan ensures that the right individuals (employees, stakeholders, authorities) receive timely and accurate updates, preventing confusion and facilitating effective coordination during security events.

name: Encrypt your data in transit
description: ## Why? Data sent over networks can be intercepted and read - the encryption ensure it won’t be intelligible. It secure it from potential threats.   ## What? If you don’t have your own network or are not using FTP, you only need to focus on web traffic.

name: Implement an MDM
description: ## Why? An MDM enforces consistent security policies, ensures encryption and up-to-date patches, and can remotely lock or wipe devices if they’re lost, reducing the risk of data breaches and unauthorized access.

name: List of your assets
description: ## Why? The assets storing/processing data are potential vulnerabilities that need to be known, properly managed, and secured to reduce your risk exposure.

name: Protect your employees devices
description: ## Why? Mobile devices store and access sensitive data; proper configuration (screen lock, FileVault, firewall, etc.) reduces vulnerabilities and maintains compliance with security policies.

name: Create KPI aligned with ISMS objectives
description: ## Why? KPIs provide quantifiable metrics to track security performance, identify trends, and demonstrate the effectiveness of your security initiatives, ensuring continuous alignment with ISMS objectives.

name: Define ISMS objectives
description: ## Why? Clear ISMS objectives ensure that all security activities are aligned with business priorities, enabling focused resource allocation, measurable progress, and continuous improvement in your security posture.

name: Define the scope of the ISMS
description: ## Why? Proper scoping of the ISMS ensures security controls remain relevant, covering all critical assets, technologies, and processes without leaving any newly added components at risk.

name: Determine internal & external threats for ISMS scope
description: ## Why? Knowing which threats your organization faces allows you to allocate resources effectively, implement appropriate countermeasures, and tailor your ISMS to the actual risk environment, improving resilience.

name: Develop a risk treatment plan
description: ## Why? Having a clear plan to address each risk ensures accountability and drives progress on remediation, promoting a structured approach to reducing your overall risk exposure.

name: Establish documentation system
description: ## Why? A central documentation system ensures information is accessible, consistent, and easily updated. It simplifies audits, maintains clarity across teams, and helps prove compliance with internal and external requirements.

name: Provide terms of service
description: ## Why? Terms of service set clear legal and ethical boundaries, protect your organization from misuse, and clarify user responsibilities.

name: Monitor USB usage (endpoint security)
description: ## Why? Restricting and reviewing USB usage helps close an overlooked attack vector, ensuring sensitive data isn’t copied offsite and external malware-laden drives don’t compromise the network.

name: Encrypt your data storage
description: ## Why? By encrypting data, you ensure that loss or theft of a device won’t result in a data breach. It also protects sensitive information from unauthorized access.   ## What? You need to ensure that all sensitive data stored is encrypted.

name: Data inventory
description: ## Why? Having an accurate and up-to-date inventory of all your data assets (databases, cloud storage or even file shares) enables you to be exhaustive in how you treat your data safety.

name: Prove customer data is deleted upon request
description: ## Why? Being able to demonstrate data deletion meets regulatory requirements (like GDPR), and protects you from potential legal consequences if data isn’t erased or retention policies aren’t followed.

name: Have a statement of applicability
description: ## Why? A statement of applicability clarifies your chosen security controls, ensures transparency in your compliance approach, and reduces confusion about what is in-scope for audits or reviews.

name: Have all policies approved and signed
Have an internal audit
description: ## Why? Annual internal audits provide an objective view of security posture, ensuring controls are effective and highlighting areas that need remediation.

name: Have the scoping document signed by leadership
description: ## Why? Leadership sign-off cements organizational support, fosters clarity on ISMS coverage, and ensures everyone responsibilities.

name: Identify all stakeholders to scope the ISMS
description: ## Why? Understanding the range of stakeholders ensures that security measures account for all relevant interests and obligations, preventing oversight of critical parties and enabling inclusive risk management.

name: Identify threats & mitigations (fire extinguisher etc)
description: ## Why? Recognizing environmental and physical risks ensures you can proactively deploy measures.

name: Maintain a compliance register
description: ## Why? A formal register of compliance requirements provides clarity on obligations, helps manage compliance tasks systematically, and reduces the risk of overlooked or outdated mandates leading to legal or regulatory issues.

name: Perform a risk assessment
description: ## Why? Risk assessments provide the foundation for your security strategy, highlighting where resources should be directed to mitigate the most significant risks, ensuring your approach remains both proactive and cost-effective.

name: Plan security improvements
description: ## Why? Proactively addressing identified weaknesses maintains a strong security posture, aligns with evolving risks, and demonstrates continuous commitment to protecting systems and data.

name: Schedule management review
description: ## Why? Management reviews keep leadership involved, ensure alignment with business goals, and validate that security initiatives are effectively reducing risk.

name: Track and address non conformities
description: ## Why? Handling nonconformities promptly maintains the integrity of your ISMS, prevents small oversights from escalating into serious breaches, and supports continuous improvement.

name: Define roles & responsibilities for ISMS
description: ## Why? Clear accountability and authority lines within your ISMS help avoid confusion, empower individuals to act decisively, and foster a security culture where each participant understands their own critical role in the organization’s protection.

name: Define roles & responsibilities to ensure adequate resources
description: ## Why? Ensuring the right people are in the right roles supports smooth security operations, accelerates incident response, and reduces oversights caused by confusion over who is responsible for key tasks.

name: Integrate security checklist in your onboarding process
description: ## Why? It is the perfect timing to ensure that every employees has (not exhaustive): - accepted and signed all documents - the access needed to perform his/her tasks - started his/her security training

name: Know your recruits
description: ## Why? When recruiting someone, you want to be sure of who you are hiring: by performing reference checks (it can also be background checks), you add an additional layer of certainty on the candidate by looking for potential red flags in the candidate’s past (history of unethical behavior, harassment, fraud, etc..).  ## What? Recruitment is key, especially early stage, so you are probably already doing it right, it is only about documenting it.

name: Ensure proof of employment
description: ## Why? Having signed employment contracts reduces legal ambiguity, ensures clear understanding of obligations, and underpins accountability.

name: Properly off-board your employees
description: ## Why? Yes, people will leave your company (either by your decision or theirs). And you want to be prepare! If an early employee leaves and you forgot to change the ownership on his/her document, you might lose the documents.  Also, you want to be sure people can’t access the company data or systems once they left!

name: Train your employees on security
description: ## Why? Your employees are the main target of cyber threats (especially phishing and social engineering), and education is one of the best way to reduce risk. Awareness of your employees will improve your company security.

name: Scan for Security updates
description: ## Why? An automated security scanning software on your infrastructure components enables you to fix potential vulnerabilities as soon as they are uncovered.

name: Enable autoscaling
description: ## Why? Autoscaling helps maintain stable performance under changing workloads, preventing outages from sudden traffic spikes while optimizing costs when load decreases. It also reduces manual intervention, freeing your team to focus on more critical tasks.

name: Keep an history of all your changes
description: ## Why? Infrastructure as Code (IaC) makes sure all your infrastructure changes are done in a standardized and repeatable process - the chance of human error is lower. Moreover, IaC enables version control and peer reviews. When growing, you will have to do it - the earlier the better (later, it can become really painful).  ## What? **Option 1:** If you don’t want an IaC, provide a screenshot of the logs of your infrastructure changes.  **Option 2:** If you already have an IaC, we only need a screenshot of it.  **Option 3:** If you don’t have one, we recommend Terraform - the documentation is available [here](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/tutorials).

name: Run a penetration test
description: ## Why? It is a good way to safeguard your company’s data. It is a real-life simulation of attack scenarios on your company: it enables you to identify potential vulnerabilities that can be fixed before being exploited.

name: Restrict public access on your infrastructure
description: ## Why? Public access to your company's infrastructure is a serious security risk. By configuring your cloud provider to restrict public access, you can reduce the risk of unauthorized access to your sensitive data and systems.

name: Setup role based access
description: ## Why? In order to minimize the threat of someone getting access to something they should not, we follow the **least privilege principle:** access is limited to what's necessary for job duties. We need to define which function should have access to which tool in your company to serve as a reference when providing access to people (password manager vaults etc.).

name: Enable 2FA on critical services
description: ## Why? In order to minimize the threat of someone getting access to something they should not, we follow the **secure principle:** nobody can easily get access to data/systems.   We need to ensure that if someone has access to your password, they still cannot log into your account. Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds extra layers of security by requiring users to provide additional authentication factors beyond their passwords. The most standard solution is 2FA: your password + something else.   ## What? Enable 2FA across all your systems. If you don’t want to activate it everywhere, prioritize: - System containing sensitive data - System related to your network, infrastructure or production.

name: Conduct an Access Reviews
description: ## Why? A formal/explicit process to review employee access on a quarterly/yearly basis is a must have in terms of security hygiene.   ## What? Every 3 or 6 months, plan an “Access review session” with the relevant people to audit accesses on all systems (that is another good reason to enable SSO). You need to ensure everyone has the proper access for his/her job - an account inactive for the last 90 days can probably be disable. If you proceed to any change, document it in the minutes of the meeting - those minutes will be asked for subsequent audits.

name: Manage your service accounts
description: ## Why? You don’t want to use the “default” service account, it has way too many permissions - it is a super administrator. Even GCP is asking you not to use theirs, it is only here for legacy reasons. In the same idea, grant your service accounts only what is necessary.

name: Enable code scanning
description: ## Why? It ensures that potential security flaws are detected early. This proactive approach strengthens your security posture and helps maintain high code quality.

name: Build an incident response process
description: ## Why? An **incident response plan** is crucial for quickly identifying, containing, and resolving incidents, minimizing potential disruptions. It ensures you’re prepared effectively and that you keep your operations running smoothly, even in the face of unexpected threats.

name: Maintain history of incident review
description: ## Why? Retaining incident review records helps you refine your incident response plans, avoid repeated mistakes, and provide an audit trail for accountability and compliance.

name: Have distinct coding environment
description: ## Why? Not doing everything directly in production, especially for testing purpose, is for the best.

name: Cloud datacenter physical security
description: ## Why? You know how critical a data center is. You don’t want unauthorized people to access it.

name: Keep your logs
description: ## Why?  Logs help you to detect and investigate security incidents and troubleshoot operational issues. They provide an audit trail.  ## What?  You should consider a retention period of at least 90 days, and up to 1 year.

name: Synchronize clock on infra
description: ## Why?  Accurate timestamps are critical for correlating logs, investigating incidents, and maintaining consistent audit trails. A centralized clock source reduces confusion, improves analysis, and streamlines incident management.

name: Document your development lifecycle
description: ## Why? Formalizing a proper development lifecycle helps your engineer in their jobs and helps you to scale your team. It reduces the chances of human error.

name: Set-up a WAF
description: ## Why? It filters malicious traffic, preventing attacks (like SQL injections and cross-site scripting) and mitigates risks of service disruptions. Additionally, it can masks your origin IP, reducing exposure and limiting direct access to your infrastructure.

name: Implement physical access control
description: ## Why? Even if you do most of your business online, you still have offices, computers or even printed document: you need to make sure those assets are physically secured (we will focus on the digital access later).

name: Keep track of visitors
description: ## Why? Even if you do most of your business online, you still have offices, computers or even printed document: you need to make sure those assets are physically secured (we will focus on the digital access later) regarding visitors.  ## What? In your policies, we will mention that all visitors must be accompanied by an employee at all times. On your end, you need to keep track of them (and accompany them).

name: Implement physical security measures
description: ## Why? Physical safeguards bolster your security stance by preventing theft, deterring unauthorized access, and providing forensic evidence in case of breaches.

name: Have testing procedures
description: ## Why? Systematic testing ensures reliability, quickly uncovers potential security or functionality gaps, and upholds quality standards. It leads to fewer incidents in production.

name: Require Pull Requests (PRs)
description: ## Why? Requiring pull requests and code reviews ensures higher code quality and security by allowing multiple team members to catch bugs, inefficiencies, and potential vulnerabilities before code is merged. It also promotes collaboration, knowledge sharing, and accountability within the team. This process helps prevent issues in production and maintains adherence to coding standards.

name: Set-up dependancy vulnerability alerts
description: ## Why? It ensures your project stays secure and up-to-date without manual tracking of dependencies. It also reduces the risk of using outdated or insecure libraries in your codebase.

name: Set-up 2FA for all contributors
description: ## Why? It reduces the risk of account compromise for all contributors, especially the ones not in your company.

name: Help the auditor with a data-flow diagram
description: ## Why? The auditor doesn’t know your company and your systems. Providing him with a diagram that show all account data accross your systems & networks will enable him/her to understand your challenges faster and also to better evaluate your tradeoffs (when needed). It will also help you be 100% clear on how you process your data, and help with onboarding.

name: Follow news in cybersecurity
description: Monitoring emerging attack trends and security patches enables proactive defenses, letting you adapt strategies quickly and remain resilient as the threat landscape evolves.

name: Setup an access request process
description: ## Why? In order to minimize the threat of someone getting access to something they should not, we follow the **continuous update principle:** making sure the privileges are up to date. We need to setup a proper process to define how we grant and revoke access to different systems.

name: Be automatically notified of issues
description: ## Why? Setting up alerting allows you to respond quickly and minimize downtime or potential data breaches. It ensures that important events, such as unauthorized access or system failures, are addressed promptly.  ## What? Don't implement alerts for everything. **Focus on critical events** - if you have alerts on everything, it's not alerting anymore.  You should consider (not mandatory or exhaustive): - **Resource Utilization**: Monitor high CPU, memory, or disk usage to prevent downtime or system crashes. - **System Downtime**: Set alerts for system unavailability or critical services going offline. - **Network Traffic Anomalies**: Monitor for unusual spikes or patterns in network traffic that could indicate a potential attack.  - **Unauthorized Access Attempts:** Track and alert on failed logins, unusual login locations, or excessive login attempts.

name: Configure logs and implement real-time monitoring
description: ## Why? It allows you to detect and respond to potential security incidents or system failures immediately, minimizing downtime and reducing the risk of data breaches. It maintain visibility into system performance and security events. ## What? Once you have selected the tool you are using and implemented it, you need to implement your first dashboard (if not already the case). At least, we think you should be able to follow: - Availability: Resource usage (CPU, memory, storage), System downtime event     - Optional: Uptime, latency - Access: Failed log attemps, unauthorized access, MFA usage - Integrity: Error rate (eg. rate of 500s), data loss or corruption (inc. transaction failures)
